daily: Daily Quote: “When you want to know how things really work, study them when they’re coming apart.” - William Gibson
Person of the day: Ismail al-Jazari
Daily Fact: Around 20% of all YouTube videos are music related.
Daily Quote: "All our dreams can come true, if we have the courage to pursue them." - Walt Disney
Person of the day: Edwin H. Armstrong
Daily Fact: Anthony Greco was the first man ever arrested for sending spam messages in 2005.
Daily Quote: “A person who never made a mistake never tried anything new.” - Albert Einstein
Person of the day: Elisha Graves Otis
Daily Fact: Using a hands-free device to talk on the phone while driving is shown to be equally or more dangerous than driving drunk.
Daily Quote: "Creativity is intelligence having fun." - Albert Einstein
Person of the day: Sir Rowland Hill
Daily Fact: In japan, instead of a "Man in the moon," people see a "Rabbit in the moon."
Daily Quote: “The trick to having good ideas is not to sit around in glorious isolation and try to think big thoughts. The trick is to get more parts on the table.” - Steven Johnson
Person of the day: Otto Lilienthal
Daily Fact: The Comic Sans font is widely known as the world’s most hated font.

Daily Quote: “For the birth of something new, there has to be a happening. Newton saw an apple fall; James Watt watched a kettle boil; Roentgen fogged some photographic plates. And these people knew enough to translate ordinary happenings into something new...” - Alexander Fleming
Person of the day: Louis Pasteur
Daily Fact: The name Yahoo was created by Jonathan Swift for his book Gulliver’s Travels (1726) – which explained a “yahoo” to be a really ugly person.
Daily Quote: "Education is the key to unlock the golden door of freedom.”  - George Washington Carver, inventor of multiple agricultural and food products
Person of the day: Leonardo Da Vinci
Daily Fact: Doug Engelbart created the very first computer mouse from wood in 1964.
Daily Quote: “When one door closes, another door opens; but we so often look so long and regretfully upon the closed door, that we do not see the ones which open for us.” – Alexander Graham Bell
Person of the day: Shunpei Yamazaki
Daily Fact: In 2000, the FIFA 2001 game used Scratch & Sniff technology on their discs; it had the scent of a football stadium turf on the disc.

Daily Quote: “It is the lone worker who makes the first advance in a subject: the details may be worked out by a team, but the prime idea is due to the enterprise, thought, and perception of an individual.” - Alexander Fleming
Person of the day: John Wesley Hyatt
Daily Fact: Google rents out goats from a company called California Grazing to help cut down the amount of weeds and brush at Google HQ!
Daily Quote: "It had long come to my attention that people of accomplishment rarely sat back and let things happen to them. They went out and happened to things." - Leonardo da Vinci
Person of the day: Alfred Nobel
Daily Fact: There are over 35 billion Google searches every month.
Daily Quote: “I see no advantage in these new clocks. They run no faster than the ones made 100 years ago.” ― Henry Ford
Person of the day: Joseph-Marie Jacquard
Daily Fact: In 1994, the company who had a patent on GIFs tried to charge a fee for using GIFS. The PNG was invented as an alternative, and the company backed down.
Daily Quote: “Give me but a firm spot on which to stand, and I shall move the earth.” – Archimedes
Person of the day: Samuel Colt
Daily Fact: Surgeons who grew up playing video games make 37% fewer mistakes.

Daily Quote: "A good scientist is a person with original ideas. I good engineer is a person who makes a design that works with as few original ideas as possible. There are no prima donnas in engineering." - Freeman Dyson
Person of the day: Grace Murray Hopper
Daily Fact: The average computer user blinks seven times a minute, the normal rate is twenty times per minute.

Daily Quote: "Once the wise man was asked why scientists always knock on the doors of the wealthy, while the wealthy do not come close to the doors of scientists, and he replied: Scientists are well aware of the use of money, but the rich are ignorant of the nobility of science." - Al-Biruni
Person of the day: Eli Whitney
Daily Fact: The Atari 2600 was originally called “Atari Video Computer System”, or “VCS”.
Daily Quote: “The more you like yourself, the less you are like anyone else, which makes you unique.” - Walt Disney
Person of the day: James Starley
Daily Fact: The astronauts of Apollo 11 couldn’t get life insurance, so instead they signed photos that their families could auction in case the landing went wrong.
Daily Quote: "Ideas are like rabbits. You get a couple and learn how to handle them, and pretty soon you have a dozen." - John Steinbeck
Person of the day: George Stephenson
Daily Fact: The very first Apple logo featured Sir Isaac Newton sitting underneath a tree, with an apple about to hit his head.
Daily Quote: "When something is important enough, you do it even if the odds are not in your favor." - Elon Musk
Person of the day: John Deere
Daily Fact: It is estimated that one in every eight couples in the U.S. who went on to marry each other met online.
Daily Quote: “Genius is one percent inspiration, ninety-nine percent perspiration.”  - Thomas Edison

Daily Fact: Almost half the world’s population has never made a phone call.
Daily Quote: "It's kind of fun to do the impossible." - Walt Disney

Daily Fact: Some viking chiefs were buried inside their ships.
Daily Quote: “Science knows no country, because knowledge belongs to humanity, and is the torch which illuminates the world.” – Louis Pasteur

Daily Fact: Depending on the speed of the wind, some clouds travel up to 100 miles per hour across the sky.
Daily Quote: "Do or do not, there is no try!" - Yoda

Daily Fact: The original URL for Yahoo was http://akebono.stanford.edu
Daily Quote: "Ethical teaching is weakened if it is tied up with dogmas that will not bear examination." - Margaret E. Knight, inventor of the paper bag machine

Daily Fact: 86% of people try to plug their USB devices upside down.
Daily Quote: "I guess that's just the life of an inventor: What people do with your ideas takes you totally by surprise." - Stephanie Kwolek, inventor of Kevlar

Daily Fact: Bill Gates house was designed using a Macintosh Computer.
Daily Quote: "Design is not just what it looks like and feels like. Design is how it works." - Steve Jobs

Daily Fact: You lose about 50 to 100 hairs a day.
Daily Quote: "To the optimist, the glass is half full, to the pessimist, the glass is half empty. To the engineer, the glass is twice as big as it needs to be." - Anonymous
Person of the day: Cai Lun
Daily Fact: The English word for red panda is ‘Firefox’ which is where the browser gets its name from – this means the Firefox logo is actually a red panda, not a fox!

Person of the day: Charles Townes
Daily Fact: A seahorse can move its eyes in opposite directions—all the better to scan the water for food and predators.
Daily Quote: “Engineering or technology is the making of things that did not previously exist, whereas science is the discovering of things that have long existed." - David Billington
Person of the day: Joseph and Étienne Montgolfier
Daily Fact: Facebook took 2 years to reach a market audience of 50 million.
Daily Quote: "The short successes that can be gained in a brief time and without difficulty are not worth much." - Henry Ford
Person of the day: Alexander Graham Bell
Daily Fact: A cat's tail contains nearly 10 percent of all the bones in its body.
Daily Quote: “You never change things by fighting the existing reality. To change something, build a new model that makes the existing model obsolete.” - Buckminster Fuller

Daily Quote: "Whatever you do, do it well." – Walt Disney

Daily Fact: Someone on Twitter who has a million or more followers is known as a “Twillionaire”.

Person of the day: Claude-Étienne Minié

Daily Quote: “Energy and persistence conquer all things.” – Benjamin Franklin

Daily Quote: “Math is my Passion. Engineering is my Profession.” - Wilfred James Dolor

Daily Fact: The first alarm clock could only ring at 4 a.m.

Daily Fact: The domain name www.YouTube.com was registered 14th February 2005.
Daily Quote: “Perfection is achieved, not when there is nothing more to add, but when there is nothing left to take away.” - Antoine de Saint-Exupery
Person of the day: Tim Berners-Lee
Daily Fact: The 30th of November is known as “Computer Security Day“.

Daily Fact: People reportedly prefer blue toothbrushes over red ones.

Person of the day: Richard Buckminster Fuller
Daily Fact: Hearing is the fastest human sense. A person can recognize a sound in as little as 0.05 seconds.
Daily Quote: “Normal people believe that if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it. Engineers believe that if it ain’t broke, it doesn’t have enough features yet.” - Scott Adams
Person of the day: Paul Müller

Daily Fact: In 2004, the “at” symbol used in emails (@) became the first new character to be added to Morse code in several decades! The new character, known as the “Commat” consists of the signals for both A (dot-dash), and C (dash-dot-dash-dot) with no space or break in between.
Daily Quote: "What is now proved was once only imagined." - William Blake
Person of the day: Virginia Apgar
Daily Fact: Gecko feet have millions of tiny hairs that stick to surfaces with a special chemical bond and let them climb walls and hang on by just one toe.
Daily Quote: "Be a yardstick of quality. Some people aren't used to an environment where excellence is expected." - Steve Jobs
Person of the day: Hedy Lamar
Daily Fact: Spending 1 hour a day on Social Media reduces the probability of a child being completely happy with their life by 14%.
Daily Quote: “Whenever you are asked if you can do a job, tell ‘em ‘Certainly I can!’ Then get busy and find out how to do it.” - Theodore Roosevelt
Person of the day: Charles Babbage
Daily Fact: The founder of Microsoft, Bill Gates, was a college drop out.

Daily Quote: “Aeroplanes are not designed by science, but by art in spite of some pretence and humbug to the contrary. I do not mean to suggest that engineering can do without science, on the contrary, it stands on scientific foundations, but there is a big gap between scientific research and the engineering product which has to be bridged by the art of the engineer.” - British Engineer to the Royal Aeronautical Society, 1922.
Person of the day: Karl Benz and Gottlieb Daimler
Daily Fact: The quills on african porcupines are as long as three pencils.
Daily Quote: "I cannot emphasize the importance of a good teacher." - Temple Grandin, inventor of multiple animal handling devices

Daily Fact: Komodo dragons can devour 5 pounds of meat in less than a minute. Any extra fat they eat is stored in their tails.

Person of the day: Christiaan Huygens
Daily Fact: Although GPS is free for the world to use, it costs $2 million per day to operate. The money comes from American tax revenue.

Daily Quote: "I didn't have a fellow at the time, so I had to do it all myself. I had to ... appreciate that as a woman, I was strong, complete, adequate." - Bette Nesmith Graham, inventor of Liquid Paper

Don’t let the noise of other opinions drown your own inner voice. And most important, have the courage to follow your heart and intuition, they somehow already know what you truly want to become.” - Steve Jobs

Daily Fact: Google’s first ever Tweet on Twitter was in February 2009, and reads “I’m 01100110 01100101 01100101 01101100 01101001 01101110 01100111 00100000 01101100 01110101 01100011 01101011 01111001 00001010.” Translating from binary into English, this tweet says “I’m feeling lucky.”

Daily Fact: Opal has been discovered on mars.
Daily Fact: In May 2017, Samsung were given permission to carry out trials of a self-driving car in South Korea.
Daily Fact: In 1822, Charles Babbage created the first computer.
Daily Fact: The chinese giant salamander can grow to be 6 feet (1.8 m) long, making it the largest salamander in the world.
Daily Fact: Facebook has a blue color scheme because the creator, Mark Zuckerberg cannot see the colors red & green.
Daily Fact: In 1973, the very first mobile phone call was made by Martin Cooper, who was an employee of Motorola. The call was made from the streets of New York City.
Daily Fact: 1024 Gigabytes is equal to 1 Terabyte. 1024 Terabytes is equal to 1 Petabyte, and 1 Petabyte can hold 13.3 years of HD-TV video.
Daily Fact: All the letter combinations from aaa.com to zzz.com have already been registered.
Daily Fact: Amazon now sells more eBooks than it does printed books!
Daily Fact: The tv remote is the dirtiest item in a typical household, hospital, or hotel room.

Daily Fact: A Welshman threw away a hard drive containing a staggering sum of 7,500 bitcoins. The sum equates to almost $32 million and the man will never be able to retrieve it as it was already buried under a hefty 25,000 cubic meters of rubbish in 2013.
Daily Fact: You can buy eel flavored ice cream in japan.
Daily Fact: It's considered rude to write in red ink in portugal.
Daily Fact: Originally, the design for the first iPhone was literally the shape of an apple.
Daily Fact: There are Braille accessories for smart phones.
Daily Fact: The first country to build drones was Israel, with Israel Aerospace Industries heading the charge in terms of export numbers.
Daily Fact: It would take 100 earths, lined up end-to-end, to stretch across the face of the sun.
Daily Fact: It is estimated that spammers only receive 1 reply for every 12 million emails that they send out
Daily Fact: Remember MySpace? Well it still has over 200 million registered users.
Daily Fact: Apple have a ‘no smoking’ ban regarding their computers, which means if you smoke while using an Apple computer, you void the warranty.
Daily Fact: Spotted hyenas can digest skin and bones.
Daily Fact: You cannot reverse a Bitcoin transaction, or be forced to pay.
Daily Fact: In general, people tend to read as much as 10% slower from a screen than from paper.
Daily Fact: In the 1990’s, the Japanese company Hitachi-Omron Terminal Solutions created an ATM machine that heats bills to 200°C so that bacteria is killed before dispensing them.
Daily Fact: New jersey has the highest concentration of shopping malls.
Daily Fact: In 1999, PayPal was voted as one of the top ten worst business ideas.
Daily Fact: On 1st April 2005, NASA pulled a prank telling the world that they had found water on Mars.
Daily Fact: 97% of people type in random words on Google, just to see if they spelled it right.
Daily Fact: The world's smallest fruit—a utricle—is the size of a small ant.
Daily Fact: Spam mail got its name from the canned meat after a Monty Python skit that made fun of Spam as tasting “horrible and being ubiquitous and inescapable.”

Daily Fact: In January 2007, the PS3 DualShock controller won an Emmy Award for ‘Peripheral Development and Technological Impact of Video Game Controllers’ by The National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences.
Daily Fact: Google+ was developed under the code name ‘Emerald Sea’.
Daily Fact: Alaska is the only state in America that can be typed on one row of a traditional English QWERTY keyboard.
Daily Fact: Because the speed of earth's rotation changes over time, a day in the age of dinosaurs was just 23 hours long.
Daily Fact: When signing up to iTunes, if you accept their Terms & Conditions, you agree to not use it to make nuclear weapons.
Daily Fact: The term "Astronaut" comes from greek words that mean "Star" and "Sailor."
Daily Fact: Cats sleep 16 to 18 hours per day.
Daily Fact: The most common name in the world is Mohammed.(It's also my name)
Daily Fact: Karoke means "empty orchestra" in Japanese.
Daily Fact: Henry Ford produced the model T only in black because the black paint available at the time was the fastest to dry.
